title: Setting of H1, H2, Body etc to share same baseline
content:
I may be a bit misleading in the subject but Robert Bringhurst and David Blatner have mentioned it their books about setting H1, H2, Body etc so they share the same baseline without having to set to baselne, okay not so well explained but will try again

If I set the H1 to be 18/10 H2 12/16 and Body as 10/18 that is should share the same baseline or be lining up when I have columns of text, its just that I dont have my books with me to check this out and know that both those books explain how to do it so they line up with having to set in indesign align to basegrid etc.

Did I kinda make sense or you know what Im trying to say?  
All critique welcome! ›
author: Monsta

comments.content:
Achieving true shared baselines is very hard. You can never be sure which typefaces are used to display a webpage & most browsers use the top offset of a font to render type, and not the baseline like most page design programs. The different x-heights mess up sharing baselines.

Alistapart published an informative article about this:

[http://www.alistapart.com/articles/settingtypeontheweb](http://web.archive.org/web/20130516052555/http:/www.alistapart.com/articles/settingtypeontheweb "http://www.alistapart.com/articles/settingtypeontheweb")

Rob Goodlatte built a small bookmarklet to help check whether you are on the right track:

[http://robgoodlatte.com/2007/07/31/syncotype-your-baselines/](http://web.archive.org/web/20130516052555/http:/robgoodlatte.com/2007/07/31/syncotype-your-baselines/ "http://robgoodlatte.com/2007/07/31/syncotype-your-baselines/")

Hope this helps.

. . .  
Bert Vanderveen BNO
